MoC quantum dots are dispersed in a carbon film by the temperature-programmed method. The hybrid catalyst is obtained by the mixed solution method, and the hybrid catalyst is optimized by adjusting the content of CeO2 to obtain the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC with the best photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity. SEM and TEM show that there is an intimate interface contact between CeO2 and MoC-QDs/C, which provides the basis for smooth electron transfer. It is proved by XPS that there is a strong interaction force between the catalysts, which provides a evidence for electron transfer between semiconductors. It is proved by electrochemistry that the introduction of CeO2 can effectively reduce the hydrogen evolution potential and provide powerful conditions for the hydrogen production of the hybrid catalyst. The carbon film has excellent conductivity, can effectively suppresses the recombination of photo-generated carriers, and accelerate the separation of carriers between the interfaces. MoC quantum dots with high dispersibility embedded in the carbon film provide a lot of active sites for photocatalytic hydrogen production. This research provides an effective strategy for the application of ultra-thin carbon film in photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, the loading of quantum dots, and the design and synthesis of non-noble metals. Graphic abstract MoC quantum dots uniformly distributed on the carbon film are synthesized in large numbers. The carbon film between the two materials has excellent electrical conductivity, which can effectively separate photo-generated carriers and reduce the recombination rate of photo-generated carriers, which promotes the transfer of a large number of photo-generated electrons from CeO2 to MoC quantum dots and participates in photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon film MoC-QDs CeO2 Photocatalytic H2 evolution 1 Introduction With the long-term development and large-scale consumption of the petroleum industry. Nowadays, countries all over the world are not only facing the problem of environmental pollution but the problem of energy in the future is becoming more and more intractable. Hydrogen has the preponderances of high burning value and no pollution [1,2]. In recent decades, hydrogen production technology, which uses sunlight to catalyze the decomposition of water, may become one of the new green energy sources to replace traditional energy [3-6]. However, in the process of photocatalytic splitting of water for hydrogen evolution, the main problem of a single catalyst is that the photogenerated carriers have a high recombination rate. Therefore, a large number of scientific researchers have improved this defect by constructing p-n heterojunction, S-scheme heterojunction, doping, adding co-catalyst, Z-scheme heterojunction and other methods, such as NiP2/Cu3P [7], Ni-MOF-74/Ni2P/MoSx [8], MoP/CDs [9], Cu3P@CoP [10], CuI-GD/g-C3N4 [11], UiO-66-NH2 [12], Ni-B/Ni(OH)2 [13], Mo-ZnIn2S4 [14], CdS-2MBI [15], Carbon Nitride/RGO/Fe2O3 [16]. Many studies have shown that these methods can effectively improve the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity of photocatalysts. Among many metal oxides, cerium dioxide (CeO2) is considered to have great potential in the field of visible light photocatalytic hydrogen production due to its cheap, safe, non-polluting and stable performance [17]. CeO2 has not only attracted widespread attention in the field of photocatalysis [18,19] but also the catalytic effect related to surface protons in the electric field and De-methoxylation of lignin-derived 4-propylguaiacol has been gradually explored [20-23]. CeO2 has a wide bandgap, weak ability to absorb visible light, and other shortcomings [24]. Therefore, many researchers use the method of constructing heterojunction with CeO2 to improve the light absorption ability of composite catalysts and further enhance the photocatalytic performance [25,26]. Non-metallic carbon has excellent electrical conductivity [27]. In the process of visible light photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, the effective introduction of carbon can not only enhance the capture and utilization of visible light by the composite catalyst, but also promote the effective separation of charges in space [28,29]. There are not many studies on metal carbides in the field of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. In addition, the morphology of metal carbides is relatively large, which is not conducive to the exposure of hydrogen evolution sites [30-32]. Most of the researches are based on the 1 D and 2 D structures of Mo2C to further study the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution performance. However, due to the larger size, the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity is not very ideal [33,34]. In this regard, in order to further improve the photocatalytic performance of MoC, we use low-temperature stirring and mixing and high-temperature calcination methods to cleverly embed MoC quantum dots in a carbon film with excellent electron transfer properties. MoC with a smaller area will exert greater potential in the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution process, which will maximize the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution performance of the composite catalyst [35]. In this study, we cleverly embedded MoC quantum dots (MoC-QDs) into carbon films and combined CeO2 and MoC-QDs/C through a simple physical mixing method. MoC-QDs/C enhanced the capture and utilization of visible light in the hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC and stimulated more electrons and holes in the 15%-COMCC composite catalyst. Carbon film (C) could be used as an electron bridge to transfer electrons rapidly, effectively promoting the spatial separation of charge. The hydrogen yield of the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC reached 198.3 μmol within 5 h, which was 86.2 and 6.3 times that of pure CeO2 (2.3 μmol) and MoC-QDs/C(31.5 μmol), respectively. The photocatalytic hydrogen evolution cycle experiment further proved the durability of the 15%-COMCC composite catalyst. This research provides an effective strategy for the rational design of carbon film in the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution process. and the rational synthesis and design of no precious metal catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of CeO2 1.390 g cerium nitrate hexahydrate and 0.750 g ammonium bicarbonate were dissolved in a beaker containing 50 mL of deionized water, respectively. After magnetic stirring for 0.5 h, the two solutions are quickly mixed, and after stirring for 0.5 h, Stand it still for a day at 30 °C. The product is filtered, and the residual ions in the precipitate are washed with deionized water. The precipitate is placed in an 80 °C oven to dry overnight, and finally, the precipitate is placed in a tube furnace, and after calcination at 500 °C for 5 h, ribbon-shaped CeO2 sheets are obtained. 2.2 Synthesis of MoC-QDs/C 2.000 g melamine was dissolved in 100 mL of methanol solution and stirred in a water bath of 60 °C for 1 h. Then 1 mol/L of hydrochloric acid was added to adjust the solution to pH=4 and named as the solution I. First, 15 mL of ethanol was mixed with 60 mL of deionized water, then 0.618 g of solid ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate was added, and the mixture was stirred for 1 h to obtain a homogeneous solution, and named as solution II. Solution II was dropped in solution I, until it was steamed to a viscous state, and dry it at 60 °C to obtain the intermediate, and grind to obtain the dry powder. The dry powder was placed in a tubular furnace, heated to 500 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min and kept warm for 2 h, then heated to 700 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min and kept warm for 1 h. Nitrogen was used as protective gas during the whole process. After cooling, black powder was obtained, which was washed three times with deionized water and ethanol, respectively. After drying, MoC-QDs/C was obtained. 2.3 Synthesis of COMCC x%-COMCC (x% is the mass ratio of CeO2) was fabricated by the physical mixing method. Dissolve the prepared 0.040 g MoC-QDs/C and 0.004 g CeO2 in 40 mL ethanol, magnetically stirred for 20 min, and then ultrasonic treated for 30 min. The solvent was evaporated in a water bath of 70 °C and dried overnight in an oven of 60 °C to get 10%-CeO2/MoC-QDs/C, which was named as 10%-COMCC. Similarly, 15%-COMCC, 20%-COMCC, and 25%-COMCC were prepared, respectively. 2.4 Characterization The X-ray Diffraction measurement of the acquired catalysts was executed by a diffractometer operating in 40 kV and 30 mA (HORIBA Scientific, France). The apparent morphology and microscopic surface of the catalysts were characterized by a scanning electron microscope (SEM: Zeiss evo10) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (TEM: FEI Tecnai TF20). The XPS test of the sample is characterized on an energy dispersive X-ray instrument (ESCALAB 250Xi). The UV-Visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy of the sample was tested on a PerkinElmer Lambda-750 UV–Vis-NIR spectrometer, and BaSO4 was used as a reference for calibration. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the sample was characterized by ASAP2020M at 77 K. The photoelectrochemical characterization of the sample was tested on an electrochemical analyzer (VersaStat 4–400, Advanced measurement Technology, Inc) in a normal three-electrode battery. The electrolyte solution is Na2SO4 (0.2 M) aqueous solution. The transient photocurrent of the catalyst under the open circuit voltage was measured under visible light irradiation, in which a 300 W xenon lamp was used as the light source, and the filter was 420 nm. The LSV of catalysts were tested at indoor temperature with a scan rate of 5 mV s − 1. 2.5 Photocatalytic hydrogen production experiment The photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction is executed in a quartz reaction flask. First, a 15% volume fraction of triethanolamine solution (TEOA) is added, and then 10 mg EY and 10 mg sample are added. The producing hydrogen bottle was subjected to ultrasonic treatment for 20 min to make the sample uniformly dispersed, and the gas in the producing hydrogen bottle was discharged with nitrogen for 5 min. Put the producing hydrogen bottle with the sample into the multichannel simulator for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction. Take 5 mL of product from the quartz bottle with a syringe per hour, and analyze the evolution of H2 by gas chromatography (Tianmei GC7900, TCD, 13Xcolumn, N2 as carrier). 2.6 Preparation of sacrifice reagent First, the pH of a 15% triethanolamine solution is about 10.80 in the absence of foreign reagents. In order to further adjust the pH to an integer, sodium hydroxide solution and hydrochloric acid solution were added to the prepared 15% triethanolamine solution, respectively, until it was adjusted to an integer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD analysis The crystal structure and crystallinity of the catalysts were analyzed through X-ray diffraction (XRD). As shown in Fig. 1 b, the diffraction peaks of MoC-QDs/C are in good correspond with the standard card PDF#65–280 of MoC. The diffraction peaks at 36.39°, 42.28°, 61.36°, and 73.43° can be attributed to (111), (200), (220), (311) crystal planes of MoC-QDs, respectively. The bulging peaks in the range of 20°-30° are characteristic peaks of carbon film, which shows that MoC-QDs/C has been successfully prepared. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the XRD characteristic peaks of pure CeO2 are completely corresponding to the standard card PDF#81–792 of CeO2, and the diffraction peaks located at 28.52°, 33.15°, 47.46°, 56.33°, 59.08°, 69.43°, 76.70°, and 79.06° corresponded to the crystal surfaces of (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), and (420), respectively, indicating that CeO2 has been successfully prepared. After pure MoC-QDs/C coupled with CeO2, all the diffraction peaks of MoC-QDs/C and CeO2 did not appear completely in the composite catalyst, which indicated that there were crystal faces with poor crystallinity in MoC-QDs/C and CeO2. However, the main diffraction peaks of both MoC-QDs/C and CeO2 appeared in the XRD patterns of 15%-COMCC composite catalyst, which indicated that the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC was successfully obtained. 3.2 SEM and tem analysis To more directly observe the surface morphology and microstructure of the sample, the pure MoC-QDs/C, CeO2 and hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC were characterized by using scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM). It is easy to see from Fig. 2 a that CeO2 is a banded sheet structure. Fig. 2 b shows the apparent morphology of MoC-QDs/C. It is easy to see that MoC-QDs/C is an amorphous layered stack structure. Fig. 2 c shows the 15%-COMCC hybrid catalyst obtained by solvent mixing method. It is obvious from Fig. 2 c that pure CeO2 has good contact with MoC-QDs/C, which indicates that the hybrid catalyst was successfully prepared. Similarly, it can be seen from the TEM of the hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC ( Fig. 2 d) that there is a good interface contact between pure MoC-QDs/C andCeO2. Fig. 2 e show the TEM image of the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC. It can be clearly observed that the MoC-QDs are uniformly embedded on the carbon film, which indicates that the MoC quantum dots are uniformly dispersed on the carbon film material has been successfully obtained. The HRTEM of the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC is shown in Fig. 2 f. It is easy to see from the figure that there is an obvious contact interface between CeO2 and MoC-QDs/C. Through measurement, we accurately found the (111), (220), and (200) crystal planes of CeO2, and the corresponding lattice spacings are d = 0.312 nm, 0.191 nm, and 0.271 nm, respectively. Similarly, by measuring the lattice spacing of MoC-QDs, d = 0.247 nm and 0.214 nm belong to (111) and (200) crystal planes, respectively. Besides, MoC material exists in the form of quantum dots in the carbon film, and the lattice-free area is the carbon film, which shows that the MoC in the form of quantum dots is uniformly present in the ultra-thin carbon film. EDX ( Fig. 2 g) shows that the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC contains Ce, O, Mo, and C elements. The above fully proved that CeO2 and MoC-QDs were successfully compounded. 3.3 XPS analysis and results The surface element composition and chemical valence of all catalysts are characterized by means of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 3 a, the sample CeO2 is made up of Ce 4d, Ce 3d, and O 1 s. the sample MoC-QDs/C includes Mo 3d, Mo 3p, O 1 s, and C 1 s, and the sample 15%-COMCC is the makeup of Ce 4d, Ce 3d, O 1 s, Mo 3d, Mo 3p, O 1 s, and C 1 s, indicating that the catalyst CeO2, MoC-QDs/C, and the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC were successfully synthesized. Fig. 3 b-e shows the high-resolution spectra of different elements in CeO2, MoC-QDs/C, and the hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC. As shown in Fig. 3 b, there are 7 binding energy peaks in the XPS fine spectrum of Ce 3d. The binding energies at 882.53 eV, 885.49 eV, 889.02 eV and 898.46 eV can be attributed to Ce 3d94f2Ln−1, Ce 3d94f1Ln, 3d94f1Ln−1 and Ce 3d94f0Ln of Ce 3d5/2, respectively [36]. And the characteristic peaks at 901.10 eV, 907.63 eV and 916.93 eV are caused by Ce 3d3/2 [37-39]. Fig. 3 c shows the XPS fine spectrum of O 1 s, with binding energy located at 529.50 eV and 531.35 eV, respectively, belonging to lattice oxygen (OL) and deficient regions of oxygen (OV) [25]. In Fig. 3 d, the characteristic peak of Mo 3d is divided into two diffraction peaks, Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2, due to the reason of spin-orbit coupling. The two peaks of binding energy at 228.93 eV and 232.20 eV were caused by Mo6+ 3d5/2 and Mo6+ 3d3/2, and the diffraction peaks at 230.55 eV and 235.11 eV could belong to Mo4+ 3d5/2 and Mo4+ 3d3/2. The characteristic peaks located at 232.94 eV and 236.15 eV correspond to Mo3+ 3d5/2 and Mo3+ 3d3/2, where the oxidation states of Mo6+ and Mo4+ indicate that the sample surface is slightly oxidized (MoO2 and MoO3) [35]. As shown in Fig. 3 e, the characteristic peak at 283.60 eV can be related to the Mo-C bond of MoC-QDs/C. And the characteristics of the binding energy at 284.79 eV, 285.99 eV, and 289.99 eV belong to CO, CC, and O C = O bond, respectively, which indicates that partially oxidized sp2 hybrid C has appeared in the carbon film [40]. 3.4 BET analysis The pore size and specific surface area of the sample are studied by nitrogen adsorption and analytical isotherm characterization at 77 K. Fig. 4 a shows the isotherms of the three catalysts, and it is easy to see that all three samples belong to type IV isotherms. The data in Table 1 are obtained by calculation. The specific surface areas of sample CeO2, MoC-QDs/C, and 15%-COMCC is 13 m2/g, 106 m2/g, and 30 m2/g, respectively. The specific surface area of the composite catalyst has been reduced compared with sample MoC-QDs/C, which is probably due to the fact that the decoration of CeO2 changes the quality of the MoC-QDs/C. Nevertheless, the hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC produces the largest amount of hydrogen (198.3 μmol) in the photocatalytic process, which shows that the specific surface area cannot be the main factor affecting the hydrogen production activity of the catalyst [41]. The average pore size and pore volume of the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC are 0.12 cm3/g and 16.72 nm, respectively, which are significantly increased compared with the average pore size (0.02 cm3/g) and pore volume (7.48 nm) of pure CeO2. This provides favorable conditions for sacrificing reagents to enter the photocatalyst. As shown in Fig. 4 b, the pore size distribution of the catalysts can be estimated by BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) rule. The vast majority of pore sizes of the three catalysts are evenly distributed between 2 and 30 nm, which fully proves that all three samples are mesoporous materials. 3.5 Photocatalytic performance evaluation The photocatalytic hydrogen production activity of all samples under visible light irradiation was further studied. The total amount of photocatalytic hydrogen production in all samples are the amount of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution in 5 h. It is easy to see from Fig. 5 a that the total hydrogen evolution (198.30 μmol) of the hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC is 86.2 and 6.3 times that of pure CeO2 (2.3 μmol) and MoC-QDs/C (31.5 μmol), respectively. The composite catalyst was optimized by adjusting the content of CeO2 in the composite catalyst. As shown in Fig. 5 b, the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC showed the best photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity. However, it is not the case that the higher the CeO2 loading quantity is, the higher the hydrogen evolution quantity is. When the CeO2 content is greater than 15%, the hydrogen evolution performance of the hybrid catalyst began to decrease, which could due to the CeO2 content affect the dispersion of the composite catalyst, the contact with water molecules and sacrifice reagent TEOA, and even has an impact on the ability of the catalyst to absorb visible light [41]. Further study the influence of the system environment on the catalyst activity by changing the pH value of the reaction environment. As shown in Fig. 5 c, it is obvious that the hydrogen production of the hybrid catalyst reached the maximum (195.20 μmol) within 5 h at pH=9. In the pH range of 8–11, the hydrogen production range of the hybrid catalyst is volcanically distributed. This is because the presence of H + in weakly alkaline conditions causes protonation of TEOA, and the protonated TEOA can not provide electrons to EY3 ⁎, resulting in EY3 ⁎ can not be reduced to EY [42]. Under strong alkaline conditions, there could be a large amount of OH− in the reaction solution, the concentration of H + is greatly reduced, which ultimately greatly reduces the photocatalytic activity of the catalyst [43]. The hydrogen production cycle experiment was carried out on the hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC to further studied the durability of the hybrid catalyst. In order to further study the effects of different sacrifice reagents on photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, 10% methanol solution, 15% triethanolamine solution and 10% lactic acid solution were mixed with the compound catalyst 15%-COMCC for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, respectively. As shown in Fig. 5 d, it is an overjoyed thing that the hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC showed excellent photocatalytic performance of hydrogen evolution in 15% tracethanolamine solution, and the amount of hydrogen evolution reached to 198.28 μmol within 5 h. However, the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC did not perform well in the system of 10% methanol and 10% lactic acid, and the amount of hydrogen evolution reached to 1.31 μmol and 1.65 μmol within 5 h, respectively, which may be related to the characteristics of the catalyst. In order to further study the contribution of EY to photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, the hydrogen evolution experiment without EY was further carried out. As shown in Fig. 5 e, as expected, when EY is not added, the hydrogen evolution effect of the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC in the TEOA system is not ideal. However, the amount of hydrogen evolution has been greatly increased after added EY. This is the result of the interaction between EY and the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC, which cannot be attributed solely to EY. As shown in Fig. 5 f, the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC still maintains a good photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity within 15 h, which shows that the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC has better durability and high efficiency. And these excellences can be attributed to the excellent electron transfer ability of the carbon film, which continuously and effectively reduces the combination of photo-generated electrons-holes. As shown in Table 2 , the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC exhibits excellent photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity compared with other catalysts. This is caused by the uniform distribution of MoC quantum dots on the carbon film. On the one hand, the existence of MoC quantum dots has good photocatalytic activity, and on the other hand, the carbon film has good conductivity, The synergy of the two promotes the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity. 3.6 UV–vis drs and pl analysis The influence of CeO2 modification MoC-QDs/C on the optical properties were investigated by UV–Vis diffuse reflection spectrum (UV–Vis DRS). As shown in Fig. 6 a, the sample MoC-QDs/C shows the inherent characteristics of black material absorption of visible light, while pure CeO2 has poor light absorption performance, with the absorption band edge around 470 nm. Additionally, the bandgap energies of CeO2 was estimated by Tauc's Eq. (1): (1) ( a h v ) = A ( h v − E g ) n / 2 A :absorption coefficient; h : Planck constant; v :light frequency; E g :band gap energy; Where n relies on the properties of the transition, i.e., indirect transition (CeO2, n = 4) [47,48]. Therefore, as is shown in Fig. 6 b that the Eg values are calculated, i.e., 2.70 eV for CeO2. The charge transfer and separation of the sample were further studied by Steady-state photoluminescence (PL) spectra [49]. The stronger the PL signal is, the higher the recombination rate of the photogenerated electron holes in the sample is [50]. As shown in Fig. 6 c, all samples generated strong PL signals at 542 nm under the excitation of 454 nm wavelength. The PL signal of EY is the strongest, which indicates that the carrier recombination rate of EY is the highest under the excitation of visible light. The PL signal of pure CeO2 and MoC-QDs/C composite is greatly reduced, which indicates that carbon film can effectively capture and transfer electrons. The introduction of carbon film improves interfacial separation efficiency and inhibits carrier recombination. The time-resolved PL spectrum was used to further studied the charge transfer behavior of photo-generated carriers of the sample, and the exponential attenuation was used for fitting to obtain Fig. 6 d and Table 2 . As shown in Fig. 6 d, the fluorescence intensity of all samples not only showed exponential decay state but also showed the same emission characteristics. Pure EY+15%-COMCC shows a more delayed emission peak compared with EY+CeO2 and EY+MoC-QDs/C, which indicates that the fluorescence decay kinetics of EY+15%-COMCC is slower and reduced recombination of photogenerated electron holes. As shown in Table 3 , two kinds of a radiative lifetime were obtained by fitting pure CeO2 and MoC-QDs/C, and three kinds of a radiative lifetime were obtained by fitting the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC. For pure CeO2 and MoC-QDs/C, due to the rapid recombination of charge, the carrier with short-life is dominant [50]. Surprisingly, the long-life carriers of the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC dominated. The above shows that the carbon film as an electron trap can capture a large number of electrons, avoid the recombination of the charge, and thus delay the life of the charge. 3.7 Photoelectric performance analysis The electrochemical properties of all samples were further investigated by photocurrent response, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) [51]. The stronger the photocurrent response, the better the photo-generated charges space separation productivity and the longer lifetime of the sample [52]. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the photocurrent response of all samples has been carried out for 5 cycles with the light on and off. Its photocurrent response is relatively stable, and the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC has the strongest photocurrent response, which shows that the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC has a higher photo-generated charge separation efficiency and a higher charge lifetime compared to pure MoC-QDs/C and CeO2, which is similar to the result in Fig. 6 c. The reason why the photocurrent curve appears “tailing” phenomenon is that when the light source is disconnected, electrons and holes will continue to recombine, and the current will gradually decrease. It can be seen from the Fig. 7 a that MoC-QDs/C and composite catalyst 15%-COMCC has the longest tail, and the longer the tail is, the longer the composite life of electrons and holes are, which is consistent with the results of fluorescence transient life. The electron transfer resistance of the sample interface reaction process can be described by the radius of the electrochemical impedance curve [53]. The photochemical hydrogen production performance of sample CeO2, MoC-QDs, and hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC were studied through linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). Fig. 7 b shows the overpotential of MoC-QDs/C, CeO2 and the hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC, and the hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC has the lowest overpotential, which explains that the addition of an appropriate amount of CeO2 effectively reduces the hydrogen evolution potential of MoC-QDs/C. This proves the result of hydrogen evolution in Fig. 5 a from the electrochemical point of view. Fig. 7 c shows the electrochemical impedance spectra of the catalyst CeO2, MoC-QDs/C and composite catalyst 15%-COMCC. The smaller the radius of curvature, the smaller the resistance of electron transfer. What is gratifying is that it is easy to see from Fig. 7 c that after the introduction of CeO2, the radius of curvature of MoC-QDs/C has been reduced, which shows that after the introduction of CeO2, the carbon film has fully played the role of electron transfer, greatly reducing the resistance of electron transfer. 3.8 Charge transfer and separation and the possible photocatalytic mechanism Based on all the above characterization and analysis, we propose a possible charge transfer reactions and reaction mechanisms. As shown in Fig. 8 , the semiconductor photocatalyst excites a large number of photon-generated carrier under the irradiation of visible light, excited electrons absorb energy and transfer to the conduction band (CB) of the catalyst, and excited holes stay in the valence band (VB) of the catalyst. Carbon film has excellent conductivity and can transfer electrons quickly. Most of the electrons transferred to the CB of the catalyst migrate to the MoC-QDs through the carbon film, and take part in the reduction of H + under the irradiation of visible light, and a few electrons migrate directly to the MoC-QDs in contact with CeO2 to take part in the reduction reaction of H +. TEOA captures holes staying on the CeO2 valence band and is oxidized to TEOA + . At the moment, EY absorbs energy under the irradiation of visible light to form a single excited state EY1 ⁎ and then undergoes ISC (intersystem transition) to form a stable triple excited state EY3 ⁎ [54]. EY3 ⁎ captures a lot of electrons from TEOA, which makes EY3 ⁎ quenched to form EY−●. EY−● with stronger reducibility emits a large number of electrons to form the ground state EY. Part of the electrons emitted from EY−● is transferred to the MoC quantum dots through the carbon film to take part in the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction, and the other part of the electrons transferred to the CB of CeO2 is transferred to the MoC quantum dots through the above two ways to reduce H + to hydrogen. 4 Conclusions In this study, we have successfully compounded a large number of MoC quantum dot materials embedded on the carbon film through a temperature-programmed method, and successfully mixed CeO2 and MoC-QDs together through a physical mixing method. Electrochemical experiments proved that the introduction of CeO2 greatly reduced the hydrogen evolution potential of the composite material. The carbon film has excellent electron transfer performance and acts as an electronic bridge in the course of photocatalytic hydrogen production, accelerating the separation of carriers and prolonging the life of electrons. The MoC quantum dots provide a lot of liveness sites for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. The hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC with the most outstanding photocatalytic activity was obtained by adjusting the content of CeO2. The total hydrogen evolution (198.30 μmol) of the hybrid catalyst 15%-COMCC is 6.3 times that of MoC-QDs/C (31.5 μmol). And the durability of the composite material was testified through the hydrogen production cycle test. This research provides a rational tactics for the application and design of non-precious metals. coredata.dc:description: MoC quantum dots are dispersed in a carbon film by the temperature-programmed method. The hybrid catalyst is obtained by the mixed solution method, and the hybrid catalyst is optimized by adjusting the content of CeO2 to obtain the composite catalyst 15%-COMCC with the best photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity. SEM and TEM show that there is an intimate interface contact between CeO2 and MoC-QDs/C, which provides the basis for smooth electron transfer. It is proved by XPS that there is a strong interaction force between the catalysts, which provides a evidence for electron transfer between semiconductors. It is proved by electrochemistry that the introduction of CeO2 can effectively reduce the hydrogen evolution potential and provide powerful conditions for the hydrogen production of the hybrid catalyst. The carbon film has excellent conductivity, can effectively suppresses the recombination of photo-generated carriers, and accelerate the separation of carriers between the interfaces. MoC quantum dots with high dispersibility embedded in the carbon film provide a lot of active sites for photocatalytic hydrogen production. This research provides an effective strategy for the application of ultra-thin carbon film in photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, the loading of quantum dots, and the design and synthesis of non-noble metals.
coredata.dc:title: MoC quantum dots modified by CeO2 dispersed in ultra-thin carbon films for efficient photocatalytic hydrogen evolution
